newsitem.title: UK: Copper hit by new sell-off.
newsitem.headline: Copper hit by new sell-off.

text.p: Non-ferrous metal prices dived across-the-board on Thursday on the London Metal Exchange (LME) as a bear raid on copper hit sentiment throughout the sector.
The flagship copper contract crashed though successive important support levels as investment funds baled out and the liquidation triggered sell-stops and some panic selling.
The other metals, previously immune to copper's gyrations, also tumbled.
"It's madness. Copper is being sold off and everybody is looking to play it from the short side," one trader said.
Copper's volatility was highlighted by Thursday's range, with prices hitting an early peak of $2,037 a tonne. Later the three months price crashed to $1,935 before settling nervously around $1,950.
On Wednesday prices ended around $2,020. Copper had then seemed to have settled into a new slightly higher range after languishing below $2,000 since the Sumitomo Corp scandal in mid-June.
Traders said the volatility was a factor of technical trading in this volume as physical trade in copper has been quiet and the Chinese, who are major players, were sitting on the sidelines.
Aluminium, previously comfortable above $1,500, slipped to $1,486 per tonne at one stage from Wednesday's close of $1,508. Nickel slumped below $7,500 to hit $7,420, a loss of $130 on the day.
U.S. hostilities against Iraq again left commodity markets outside the petroleum sector unmoved.
Gold firmed slightly but was still capped by disappointment that it had failed to rally on the Iraq news.
Benchmark Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) wheat futures eased to $4.42-1/2 from a recent range around $4.50 a bushel.Coffee and cocoa were also just easier. Some key commodity prices at 1600 GMT
